A group is a monoid $G$ such that every element of $G$ admits an inverse. More explicitly, this means we are given a set $G$ with a law of composition $G \times G \longrightarrow G,(a, b) \longmapsto a b$, such that: (i) The law is associative, i.e., we have $(a b) c=a(b c)$ for $a, b, c \in G$. (ii) There exists $a$ unit element, i.e., an element $e \in$ such that $e a=a=a e$ for all $a \in G$. (iii) Every element $a \in G$ admits an inverse, i.e., an element $b \in G$ such that $a b=e=b a$. The group is called commutative or abelian if the law is commutative, i.e., if (iv) $a b=b a$ for all $a, b \in G$.

Given a normal subgroup $N \subset G$ of a group $G$, the factor group or the residue class group of $G$ modulo $N$, denoted $G / N$, is the group formed by the set of left cosets of $N$ in $G$ with the group operation defined by $(aN) \cdot (bN) = (ab)N$ for $a, b \in G$.

Given a polynomial f=
sum a_i X^i in R[X], the i-th coefficient a_i is called the coefficient of degree i.

For ideals $\mathfrak{a}, \mathfrak{b}$ in a ring $R$, the product $\mathfrak{a} \cdot \mathfrak{b}$ is defined as $\left\{\sum_{i=1}^{<\infty} a_{i} b_{i} ; a_{i} \in \mathfrak{a}, b_{i} \in \mathfrak{b}\right\}$.

A proper ideal $\mathfrak{m} \subsetneq R$ in a ring $R$ is called a maximal ideal if for any ideal $\mathfrak{a} \subset R$ that contains $\mathfrak{m}$, $\mathfrak{a}$ must be either $\mathfrak{m}$ or $R$.

For an integral domain $R$, the field of fractions $Q(R)$ is the set of equivalence classes of pairs $(a, b)$ where $a, b \in R$ and $b \neq 0$, under the equivalence relation defined by $(a, b) \sim (a', b')$ if and only if $ab' = a'b$.
A purely inseparable extension is a field extension where the minimal polynomial of any element in the extension has a single root, which is repeated according to the degree of the polynomial.

A ring homomorphism $\varphi: A \longrightarrow B$ is of finite type if there exists an epimorphism $\Phi: A[X_{1}, \ldots, X_{n}] \longrightarrow B$ from a polynomial ring in finitely many variables over $A$ to $B$ that extends $\varphi$. Alternatively, it can be characterized by the existence of elements $x_{1}, \ldots, x_{n} \in B$ such that $B=\varphi(A)[x_{1}, \ldots, x_{n}]$.

A normal field extension is an extension field that is the splitting field of a family of polynomials from the base field. It is a prestage to Galois extensions. An algebraic field extension \\(K \subset L\\) is called normal if it satisfies the equivalent conditions of Theorem 4: (i) Every \\(K\\)-homomorphism \\(L \longrightarrow \bar{L}\\) into an algebraic closure \\(\bar{L}\\) of \\(L\\) restricts to an automorphism of \\(L\\). (ii) \\(L\\) is a splitting field of a family of polynomials in \\(K[X]\\). (iii) Every irreducible polynomial in \\(K[X]\\) that admits a zero in \\(L\\) decomposes over \\(L\\) completely into linear factors.
Let $G$ be a group and $S \subset G$ a subset. The centralizer of $S$ in $G$ is given by $Z_{S}=\{x \in G ; x s=s x \text { for all } s \in S\} .$
A finite group G is called a p-group if the order of G is a power of p, where p is a prime number.
The kernel of \( f \) is defined as:\[\mathrm{Ker}(f) = \{ a \in A \mid f(a) = 0 \} and is hence a subset of the Domain A.\]

Generalization_Specialization_Relationsh.Explanation: A factor group (ID: 1) is a specialization of a group (ID: 0) because it is defined specifically as a group formed by the set of left cosets of a normal subgroup in another group, inheriting all properties of a group with additional structure related to the normal subgroup.

The centralizer (ID: 9) is a specialization of a group (ID: 0) because it is defined as a subset of a group that itself forms a group under the same operation, specifically those elements that commute with all elements of a given subset of the group.

A p-group (ID: 10) is a specialization of a group (ID: 0) because it is defined as a group where the order of the group is a power of a prime number, thus inheriting all group properties with additional constraints on the order.
